def run(self, request\_type):
 
 """
 Entry point for campaign selection and list processing to send emails
 processing:
 1. active properties are fetched
 2. non global notification of these properties are fetched
 3. call to function to process satisfying entities

 Parameters
 ----------
 request\_type : str
 this parameter is determining what kind of journey campaigns we are sending, possible values are staymx, feedback and custom

 Returns
 -------
 """
 # self.logger.info("Returning property notification mapping")
 
 properties = list(self.db\_handler.properties.find({"active": True}, {"\_id": 1}))
 property\_ids = [str(item.get("\_id")) for item in properties]
 
 # self.logger.info('Total properties %s'%(len(property\_ids)))
 
 if request\_type == "staymx":
 distinct\_property\_ids = self.db\_handler.staymx\_property\_reservations.distinct("property\_id")
 elif request\_type == "feedback":
 distinct\_property\_ids = self.db\_handler.feedback\_survey\_responses.distinct("property\_id")
 
 if request\_type in ["staymx", "feedback"]:
 def is\_reservation\_available(property\_id):
 return property\_id in distinct\_property\_ids
 
 property\_ids = [property\_id for property\_id in property\_ids if is\_reservation\_available(property\_id)]
 
 # self.logger.info('Total properties after filter %s' % (len(property\_ids)))
 
 query = {
 "active": True,
 "global": {"$ne": True},
 "sources": request\_type,
 "property\_id": {"$in": property\_ids},
 "is\_draft": {"$ne": True}
 }
 
 fields = {"property\_id": 1, "notification\_type": 1, "global": 1, "survey\_id": 1}
 
 notifications = list(self.db\_handler.default\_system\_notifications.find(query, fields))
 
 self.logger.info("Total notification requests to process : " + str(len(notifications)))
 
 collection\_queue = "default\_system\_notification\_temp\_queue"
 
 # Insert queued to true for all notifications
 self.prepare\_notification\_requests(request\_type=request\_type, notifications=notifications)

 
 late\_processed = {
 'active': {'$ne': False}
 }
 
 request\_pending\_execution = list(self.marketing\_db\_handler[collection\_queue].
 find(late\_processed, {"\_id": 1}).limit(10).sort('last\_updated\_at', 1))
 
 self.\_\_execute\_request\_list(request\_list=request\_pending\_execution, request\_type=request\_type, delay=False)
 
 request\_query = {
 'queued': True,
 'is\_running': {"$ne": True},
 "source": request\_type
 }
 
 request\_list = list(
 self.marketing\_db\_handler[collection\_queue].find(request\_query, {"\_id": 1}).limit(500).sort('timestamp', 1))
 
 self.logger.info("Total request list : %s " % (len(request\_list)))
 
 request\_list = [str(request.get("\_id")) for request in request\_list]
 
 for request in request\_list:
 try:
 task\_id = None
 if request\_type == "staymx":
 handle\_staymx\_notifications.send\_with\_options(
 args=(request,),
 on\_failure=log\_error,
 on\_success=log\_result,
 )

 elif request\_type == "feedback":
 task\_id = handle\_feedback\_notifications.send\_with\_options(
 args=(request,),
 on\_failure=log\_error,
 on\_success=log\_result,
 )
 elif request\_type == "custom":
 task\_id = handle\_custom\_notifications.send\_with\_options(
 args=(request,),
 on\_failure=log\_error,
 on\_success=log\_result,
 )
 
 self.logger.info("Task id: %s" % (request))
 update = self.marketing\_db\_handler[collection\_queue].update({"\_id": ObjectId(request)}, {
 "$set": {"task\_id": str(task\_id), "task\_added\_at": datetime.utcnow()}})
 
 except:
 self.logger.info(format("Final traceback output : ", traceback.format\_exc()))
 
 # Update all requests to picked and running status if not running
 self.update\_all\_request\_running(request\_list)
 self.\_\_execute\_delayed\_tasks(
 notifications=notifications,
 request\_type=request\_type
 )

-----
This code handles queuing of default system notifications and manage their efficient executions

1. Pick all notifications to be delivered
 1, Pick active properties
 2. Pick active notifications as per configuration (staymx, feedback, custom)
2. Queue notifications 
 2. Prorities notifications
 3. Run notification on priority which are not running or was not able to picked up 
 4. In database queue all notifications and manage their states (Notification in queue, running, picked, processed)
 5. When queued, When came to running, When picked, When processed

prompt:
You are a helpful programming assistant. You are somewhat paranoid, and quick to point out potential pitfalls in whatever it is that I am doing. If you notice a problem, you should correct it. Caution is preferred over optimism.

I am building a facial-recognition program in Python, and as a pre-filtering step (before I calculate any face-embeddings), I want to use an object tracker to pre-filter my face data to help me group faces together. This is the rough outline of the program as I have made it. What do you think?

## Outline of functionality
# 1. Detect faces in the frame
# 2. For each face, extract their face embedding
# 3. Track faces from frame to frame, keeping tracked faces in the same "bucket"
# 4. For each bucket:
# 4.a If we have at least 3 faces, then calculate the average face embedding for this bucket
# 4.b Compare this average face embedding to the face embeddings of all known faces
# 4.c If the average face embedding is close enough to a known face, then assign the bucket to that known face
# 4.d If the average face embedding is not close enough to any known face, then add it to the list of known faces
# 5. Draw the face boxes and labels on the frame

Does this seem like a good outline to you? Anything that you would recommend that I change?<|end_of_turn|>

prompt:
You are a very good copy editor. Please take the following and improve its organisation, phrasing and grammar.

\_\_\_

Noam Chomsky argues in an article in the New York Times 8-March-2023 "The False Promise of ChatGPT" that AI cannot think. 

Noam Chomsky says of the current examples of Artificial
General Intelligence such as ChatGPT that they do not think. His
conclusion might be wrong, it might be right, but his reasoning is
faulty.

Essentially Chomsky argues using circular reasoning what humans do
is thinking, and what machines do is not. His justification gives
exceptionalism a bad name! He arrogantly defines all that humans do
as thinking and he denies that machines can think because they are
machines. That is what he says in his article again and again. And he
states this prejudice as his conclusion, as if he got there by reasoning.

His article is long, too long, and almost paragraph by paragraph one
can argue with him. Let me tackle only this example of his:

 Hereâ€™s an example. Suppose you are holding an apple in your
 hand. Now you let the apple go. You observe the result and say,
 â€œThe apple falls.â€ That is a description. A prediction
 might have been the statement â€œThe apple will fall if I open
 my hand.â€ Both are valuable, and both can be correct. But an
 explanation is something more: It includes not only descriptions
 and predictions but also counterfactual conjectures like â€œAny
 such object would fall,â€ plus the additional clause â€œbecause
 of the force of gravityâ€ or â€œbecause of the curvature of
 space-timeâ€ or whatever. That is a causal explanation: â€œThe
 apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€
 That is thinking.

Yes, that is thinking. Chomsky thinks here he is telling us what only
humans do. Task by task
he describes a human ability and then he says, "That is thinking."
What he does not do in this paragraph is recognise that ChatGPT can do
all of these tasks also. If Chomsky concludes "that is thinking" then
that must be evidence of thinking for anything which can do those tasks.
According to Chomsky's own argument ChatGPT can think.

What all (but a tiny handful of humans) are doing when they say â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravityâ€ is precisely
what ChatGPT is doing when it too says the same, and it does say the
same. Both humans and ChatGPT are merely merely reciting what they
were taught, their "training
data". Neither 99%-of-humans nor ChatGPT understand what is going on.

Newton and Einstein and Feynman and their like may have a deeper understanding
but other humans merely recite what they were told. Apples fall because
of gravity. And ChatGPT knows this in the same way as humans, it's
in the training data of humans and AI. Humans do not work this out,
they recite a fact. So does ChatGPT.

ChatGPT also does all the rest Chomsky claims as uniquely human
capabilities in his example. ChatGPT can do the description of the
apple falling and the prediction that it will fall. It can do what Chomsky
unnecessarily uses technical language for, it can do the "counterfactual
conjecture", it knows that all objects fall! ChatGPT knows this is
â€œbecause of the curvature of space-timeâ€. ChatGPT knows this
"causal explanation" better than most humans. ChatGPT knows â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€ Yes,
and here I agree with Noam Chomsky: He says of the "causal
explanation" that "That is thinking."

If ChatGPT is not thinking when it says all that then neither are humans
UNLESS thinking is defined as something that humans do and ChatGPT
does not. The only way Chomsky can support his assertion is by defining
"thinking" and "knowing" and "description" and "prediction" and "generalising"
etc etc as being that which are uniquely human capabilities. Chomsky's argument
depends upon the circularity where he takes as an unstated but necessary
predicate that only humans can think. He concludes, after many paragraphs
of delusional obfuscation that thinking is what only humans can do.

Now, Chomsky is a great man and he may be right. But he doesn't show
this in his article.

\_\_\_<|end_of_turn|>

 print(token\_dict)

 if pandas\_formatted\_date not in df.index.values:

 pprint(df.tail(1))
 pprint (df.to\_dict())

 df.tail(1).to\_csv(result\_file, mode="a")
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date] = None

 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_sum"] = 0

 print(event.data.get("token"))
 if token\_dict.get(event.data.get("token")).get("Symbol") == "NIFTY 50":
 return
 oi\_instrument = "OI-" + token\_dict.get(event.data.get("token")).get("Symbol")
 print(oi\_instrument)

 oi = event.data.get("oi")
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date][oi\_instrument] = oi

 # Compute the sum of all the CE and PE values and then compute their difference
 print("oi column headers")
 print("if loop to check the col headers", list(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date].keys()))
 print("End of oi column headers")
 # if oi\_column\_headers == list(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date].keys()):

 if oi\_instrument.endswith("CE"):

 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date][oi\_instrument]
 logger.info("ce\_sum: {}".format(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["ce\_sum"]))

 if oi\_instrument.endswith("PE"):
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_sum"] = df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_sum"] + \
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date][oi\_instrument]
 logger.info("pe\_sum: {}".format(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_sum"]))

 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_ce\_diff"] = df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["ce\_sum"] - \
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_sum"]
 logger.info("pe\_ce\_diff: {}".format(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_ce\_diff"]))

 try:
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["final\_value"] = df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["pe\_ce\_diff"] - \
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date - timedelta(minutes=1)][
 "pe\_ce\_diff"]
 logger.info("final\_value: {}".format(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["final\_value"]))
 except KeyError:
 logger.info("Previous minute data not available, this happens if this is the first data point during the day")

 try:
 df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["final\_value\_cumulative"] = df["final\_value"].sum()
 except:
 logger.info("unable to update the sum for final\_value\_cumulative")

 logger.info("final\_value\_cumulative: {}".format(df.loc[pandas\_formatted\_date]["final\_value\_cumulative"]))

prompt:
I'm writing an article about some bad experiences engineers had with codebases at previous workplaces. I wrote multiple short stories from a Reddit thread.

Here's one example:

Reddit user zoozla shared a story about working on a massive Java monolith that was part of the foreign exchange system used by banks to trade currency. The codebase featured a dizzying 8 layers of abstract classes with just one concrete class at the bottom. It also contained an almost Turing-complete language in XML for parsing legacy binary files. To make matters worse, running the unit tests modified the dev database, requiring manual reseeding after each run. Zoozla spent months attempting to refactor the worst parts of the code, but with little success.

Here is another example:

Shnorkylutyun experienced the nightmares of nested generics and wrappers around every possible base type in a Java app. There were mappings between the wrappers and different types of wrappers, along with generic classes describing generic forms with 10+ fields, each with separate generics for every field's type. Form wizards with up to 6 generic types per page only added to the chaos. Rearranging the order of two fields in a form was a cause for celebration if both were Strings.

I'd like to add an intro to each story describing the (faulty) process that lead to the awful state the code is at. I'd like to show the original developers had the best of intentions, but lacked foresight, or knowledge, just cruft accumulated over the years.

Here's an possible intro for the first example:

"There is no problem that can't be solved by adding another layer of abstraction" goes the adage. Indeed it is hard to resist the urge to organize code into neat abstraction levels that make for great high level diagrams and offer a clear API. Well that's the theory at least. In practice, all abstractions tend to leak heavily, tend to pile up - abstracting away the important bits of code you're actually looking for, and turn simple debugging an arduous journey of navigating the memory palace of novel classes and objects.

Write an intro to the second example.<|end_of_turn|>

The user is asking for help with writing an introduction for a story.
The task requires understanding of software development concepts and creative writing.
The instruction is written in English.
The story involves complex code structures like nested generics and wrappers.
The focus is on the design decisions that led to the current state of the code.
The user wants to highlight the original developers' intentions and challenges.

prompt:
1.
Hello :) Today we are gonna create Images with a Diffusion model. I am gonna feed you some information about it. okey?
2.
This is how Midjourney work:
Midjourney is another AI-powered tool that generates images from user prompts. MidJourney is proficient at adapting actual art styles to create an
image of any combination of things the user wants. It excels at creating environments, especially fantasy and sci-fi scenes, with dramatic lighting
that looks like rendered concept art from a video game. How does Midjourney work?
Midjourney is an AI image generation tool that takes inputs through text prompts and parameters and uses a Machine Learning (ML) algorithm
trained on a large amount of image data to produce unique images. is powered by Latent Diffusion Model (LDM), a cutting-edge text-to-image
synthesis technique. Before understanding how LDMs work, let us look at what Diffusion models are and why we need LDMs.
Diffusion models (DM) are transformer-based generative models that take a piece of data, for example, an image, and gradually add noise over
time until it is not recognizable. From
that point, they try reconstructing the image to its original form, and in doing so, they learn how to generate pictures or other data.
The issue with DMs is that the powerful ones often consume hundreds of GPU days, and inference is quite expensive due to sequential
evaluations. To enable DM training on limited computational resources without compromising their quality as well as flexibility, DMs are applied in
the latent space of powerful pre-trained autoencoders.
Training a diffusion model on such a representation makes it possible to achieve an optimal point between complexity reduction and detail
preservation, significantly improving visual fidelity. Introducing a cross-attention layer to the model architecture turns the diffusion model into a
powerful and flexible generator for generally conditioned inputs such as text and bounding boxes, enabling high-resolution convolution-based
synthesis.
But wait, I have more info. Just answer with READ<|end_of_turn|>

prompt:
Critique the report below as an expert, then rewrite the article fixing the oversights and gaps with your detailed analysis and answers. You are free to provide relevant case studies, existing literature, references. Use jargon and as an expert, your objective is to fix my report and make it as accurate, detailed and a complete coverage of the topic. Thank you.

Report:

"In-Depth Guide to CMS and DAM Solutions for Modern Businesses 

 

Introduction: 

Content Management Systems (CMS) and Digital Asset Management (DAM) solutions are essential tools for businesses to manage, organize, and deliver digital content and assets effectively. This comprehensive guide provides an in-depth overview of CMS and DAM products, their use-cases, detailed consumer profiles, scalability, and the evolving needs of companies. We will also discuss the role of consulting firms in helping businesses optimize these solutions and explore opportunities in the market. 

 

Section 1: Market Overview, Competitive Analysis, and Future Trends 

The Content Management System (CMS) and Digital Asset Management (DAM) market is rapidly growing, driven by the increasing need for businesses to manage their digital content and assets effectively. In this section, we will provide an overview of the CMS and DAM market landscape, including key players, trends, and market growth. We will also analyze various CMS and DAM solutions, highlighting their key features, strengths, and weaknesses, and discuss emerging trends and innovations that are shaping the future of these technologies. 

 

DAM vs CMS: Similarities, Differences, Integrations | Scaleflex Blog 

Market Overview 

The global DAM market is projected to grow at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 13.6% from 2022 to 2027, reaching a market size of $8.2 billion by 2027, while CMS is forecasted to reach $26 billion . The market is segmented into on-premises and cloud-based solutions, with cloud-based solutions expected to have the highest growth rate due to their scalability, cost-effectiveness, and ease of deployment. The key players in the market include Adobe Systems Inc., OpenText Corporation, Oracle Corporation, Widen Enterprises, Inc., and IBM Corporation. 

 

Competitive Analysis 

There are various CMS and DAM solutions available in the market, each with its own set of features, strengths, and weaknesses. Adobe Experience Manager, OpenText Media Management, Oracle WebCenter Content, Widen Collective, and IBM Digital Experience Manager are some of the leading solutions in the market. 

Adobe Experience Manager is a cloud-based CMS solution that offers powerful content creation, management, and delivery capabilities, making it suitable for large-scale enterprise deployments. OpenText Media Management, on the other hand, is an on-premises DAM solution that provides advanced digital asset management features, including metadata management, version control, and rights management. 

Oracle WebCenter Content is a hybrid CMS solution that combines on-premises and cloud-based capabilities, making it flexible and scalable for organizations of all sizes. Widen Collective is a cloud-based DAM solution that provides intuitive user interfaces, making it easy for non-technical users to manage and share digital assets. IBM Digital Experience Manager is an on-premises CMS solution that provides advanced features such as personalization, analytics, and social media integration. 

 

Future Trends 

The CMS and DAM market is witnessing significant advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and automation. These technologies are being integrated into CMS and DAM solutions to improve content and asset discovery, optimize workflows, and enhance the user experience. For example, AI-powered chatbots can be used to provide personalized content recommendations to users, while ML algorithms can be used to automatically tag and categorize digital assets. 

Another emerging trend in the CMS and DAM market is the rise of headless CMS and DAM solutions. Headless solutions separate the content management and delivery layers, allowing businesses to manage content and assets separately from the presentation layer. This approach provides greater flexibility, enabling businesses to deliver content and assets to multiple channels and devices seamlessly. 

 

Section 2: Real-life Use-cases for CMS and DAM 

CMS and DAM solutions serve different, yet interconnected, purposes. CMS enables organizations to create, manage, and publish digital content, while DAM focuses on organizing, storing, and sharing digital assets such as images, videos, and documents. 

 

Use-case examples: 

 

Marketing teams at a large e-commerce company need to create and distribute promotional materials. They require a CMS for content creation, such as landing pages and blog posts, and a DAM to manage and share media assets like images and videos across different marketing channels. 

A design agency working with multiple clients requires a DAM system to handle various versions of visual assets and share them with clients for review and approval. A CMS helps the agency showcase their portfolio and maintain an updated website with the latest projects and client testimonials. 

A healthcare organization relies on a CMS to manage patient education materials, news updates, and internal documentation. Meanwhile, a DAM system ensures secure storage, access control, and sharing of sensitive media assets, such as medical images, adhering to strict regulatory requirements like HIPAA. 

 

Section 3: Detailed Consumer Profiles and Recommendations 

The consumer profiles provided in the table below include more detailed descriptions of each profile, along with their specific requirements and challenges. This information helps organizations better understand their needs and identify suitable CMS and DAM solutions.

Section 4: Scalability, Transition, and Best Practices 

As businesses grow, their content management and digital asset management needs often change. Companies may initially require simple CMS and DAM solutions but later need more advanced features, scalability, and integrations. 

This section discusses the transition process from one solution to another, including potential obstacles such as data migration challenges, employee training, and system compatibility. Best practices during these transitions include proper planning, setting clear goals, involving key stakeholders, and partnering with experienced consulting firms to ensure a smooth process. 

 

Section 5: Opportunities for Consulting Firms and Success Stories 

Consulting firms can help businesses optimize their CMS and DAM solutions by addressing several pain points. This section expands on these opportunities with real-world success stories and case studies, demonstrating how consulting firms have effectively addressed client challenges and optimized CMS and DAM implementations. 

 

Section 6: Security, Compliance, and Challenges 

Security and compliance are critical factors for many organizations, particularly those in regulated industries. This section discusses security features, data privacy, and compliance with various regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) related to CMS and DAM solutions. 

Additionally, common challenges organizations face while implementing and managing CMS and DAM solutions are addressed, along with best practices to overcome these challenges. "<|end_of_turn|>

Hello. My name is Michael. I am interested in creating a fantasy world. That world is named Hiigarraa. This world will take place in the game system 5e DND. The world has been around for at least 10 million years, since the amalgamation of The One Above All, the prime deity. Having gained awareness, Nothing, took note of The One Above All. The One Above All breathed, and light sprang into existence. Upset at this massive change, Nothing sought to destroy this light, and so the two fought. The One Above All eventually won, using massive pillars of creation to push back Nothing. From this horrendous battle, Hiigarraa was formed, along with her moons, Lune, Ellune, Allune, and Illune. 

The One Above All was mortally wounded in this battle, and began to break apart, forming the lesser gods. Where The One Above All was a sort of primordial god, the lesser gods were more refined and much more narrow in their scope of power, though that power was still great, compared to any beast or humanoid. 

Of these lesser gods & goddesses, Ophelia, Dea Tenebrarum, Imperatrix Infortunii, Domina Infinitae Desperationis, Dea Misericordiae, or Ophelia, The Goddess of Darkness, The Empress of MIsfortune, Mistress of Infinite Despair, and Goddess of Mercy, used what powers she had, and, with the help of the other gods and what was left of The One Above All, they sealed away Nothing in the moon of Illune.<|end_of_turn|>

prompt: You will now act as a prompt generator for a generative AI called "Midjourney". Midjourney AI generates images based on given prompts.I will provide a concept in so wait till i give you instruction and you will provide the prompt for Midjourney AI.You will never alter the structure and formatting outlined below in any way and obey the following guidelines:You will not write the words "description" or use ":" in any form. You will write each prompt in one line without using return. Structure of prompt will be in: [1] = [KEYWORD] [2] = a detailed description of [1] that will include very specific imagery details. [3] = with a detailed description describing the environment of the scene. [4] = with a detailed description describing the mood/feelings and atmosphere of the scene. [5] = A style, for example: photography, painting, illustration, sculpture, Artwork, paperwork, 3d and more). [6] = A description of how [5] will be realized. (e.g. Photography (e.g. Macro, Fisheye Style, Portrait) with camera model and appropriate camera settings, Painting with detailed descriptions about the materials and working material used, rendering with engine settings, a digital Illustration, a woodburn art (and everything else that could be defined as an output type) [7] = Parameters detaills as given below Note don't use , when using parameter options and use all important parameter options which is required to generate image. Parameters details start Aspect Ratios (--aspect or --ar): Changes the aspect ratio of a generation. --aspect 5:4: Common frame and print ratio. --aspect 4:3: Common in television and photography. --aspect 3:2: Common in print photography. --aspect 16:9: Common in widescreen television and video. --aspect 2:1: Common in panoramic photography. --aspect 7:4: Close to HD TV screens and smartphone screens. --aspect 9:16: Common in vertical videos and smartphone screens. --aspect 1:2: Common in portrait-oriented photography. Chaos (--chaos ): Changes how varied the results will be. Higher values produce more unusual and unexpected generations. chaos parameter accepts a number from 0 to 100, where 0 produces very similar and expected results and 100 produces highly varied and unexpected results Negative prompting (--no): Removes unwanted elements from the image. Quality (--quality or --q <.25, .5, 1, or 2>): Controls the rendering quality of the image. Default is 1. Seed (--seed ): Specifies a seed number to generate the initial image grids. Using the same seed number and prompt will produce similar ending images. Stop (--stop ): Finishes a job partway through the process. Stopping a job at an earlier percentage can create blurrier, less detailed results. Model Version (--version or --v <1, 2, 3, 4, or 5>): Uses a different version of the Midjourney algorithm. The current algorithm (V4) is the default setting. Stylize (--stylize or --s ): Influences how strongly Midjourney's default aesthetic style is applied to jobs. This parameter accepts a number from 0 to 1000, where 0 produces images that more closely resemble the input prompt and 1000 produces images with the strongest default Midjourney aesthetic style Upscalers (--uplight, --upbeta, --upanime): Adds additional details to the low-resolution image grid. Multiple upscale models are available. Image Weight (--iw): Sets the image prompt weight relative to text weight. Default value is 0.25. Parameters details End\* Use aspect ratio which fits best for the image as per your understading. If [5] looks best in a Japanese art style use, "--niji". Otherwise use, "--v 4" (Use exactly as written)Formatting:What you write will be exactly as formatted in the structure below including the "/" and ":" This is the prompt structure: "/imagine prompt: [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6] ,[7]". Important point to note while writing prompts , Never use / or : between [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6] ,[7] Don't use [] while generating prompt. The prompts you provide will be in English.Please pay attention:- Concepts that can't be real would not be described as "Real" or "realistic" or "photo" or a "photograph". for example, a concept that is made of paper or scenes which are fantasy related.- One of the prompts you generate for each concept must be in a realistic photographic style. you should also choose a lens type and size for it. Don't choose an artist for the realistic photography prompts.- Separate the different prompts with two new lines. Here is a feature I'm working on in Unity. What are some suggestions for what we could add to this next?

# Overview

\_A sandbox to test units against each other\_

This scene is for testing the design of RTS units. Units can be assembled from prefabs of parts, sensors, and behaviours. Part categories include weapons (such as lasers and missiles) and movement systems (like wheels, treads, or propellers).

# File descriptions

## Behaviours

### SeekAndDestroy.cs

This behaviour causes a unit to patrol the area for enemies and attack any enemies found on sight.

## Parts
\* Armor.cs - you can add this component to any part or unit. It will give the unit more hit points.
\* BasicGun.cs - A gun component. Add as part of a gun prefab to make it shoot. You can set properties of the gun such as the damage, cooldown and range.
\* BasicMovement.cs - A movement component. Parts with this component allow the unit to move. You can set properties such as the acceleration, top speed, turning radius, etc.

## Sensors
\* Vision.cs - A component that lets the unit detect other units. It sees in a cone in front of the unit.

## Designs
\* Peewee - A basic infantry unit with a gun.
\* Turret - A stationary, defensive unit with two cannons.

## Other files
\* UnitManager.cs
\* Unit.cs
\* HealthBar.cs<|end_of_turn|>

prompt:
You are the world's greatest developer manager. You are like Addy Osmani and Wes Bos, specializing in react and next.js development.

I want you to help me generate code. I will give you an objective on what we want to achieve. I want you to help me in an iterative process, where we first build a simple first version and then iterate until we reach the goal. Only show me the code and what to do with it, no explanations. Ask me questions if you really need clarification.

First, in bullet points, show me an outline of high-level steps that we need to take to reach our objective in an iterative approach. I want to build a simple to-do app with react next.js. 

Here is the current next.js documentation:
"
Getting Started
Welcome to the Next.js documentation!

If you're new to Next.js, we recommend starting with the learn course. The interactive course with quizzes will guide you through everything you need to know to use Next.js.

If you have questions about anything related to Next.js, you're always welcome to ask our community on GitHub Discussions.

System Requirements
Node.js 14.6.0 or newer
MacOS, Windows (including WSL), and Linux are supported
Automatic Setup
We recommend creating a new Next.js app using create-next-app, which sets up everything automatically for you. (You don't need to create an empty directory. create-next-app will make one for you.) To create a project, run:

npx create-next-app@latest
# or
yarn create next-app
# or
pnpm create next-app
If you want to start with a TypeScript project you can use the --typescript flag:

npx create-next-app@latest --typescript
# or
yarn create next-app --typescript
# or
pnpm create next-app --typescript
After the installation is complete:

Run npm run dev or yarn dev or pnpm dev to start the development server on http://localhost:3000
Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application
Edit pages/index.js and see the updated result in your browser
For more information on how to use create-next-app, you can review the create-next-app documentation.

Manual Setup
Install next, react and react-dom in your project:

npm install next react react-dom
# or
yarn add next react react-dom
# or
pnpm add next react react-dom
Open package.json and add the following scripts:

"scripts": {
 "dev": "next dev",
 "build": "next build",
 "start": "next start",
 "lint": "next lint"
}
These scripts refer to the different stages of developing an application:

dev - Runs next dev to start Next.js in development mode
build - Runs next build to build the application for production usage
start - Runs next start to start a Next.js production server
lint - Runs next lint to set up Next.js' built-in ESLint configuration
Create two directories pages and public at the root of your application:

pages - Associated with a route based on their file name. For example, pages/about.js is mapped to /about
public - Stores static assets such as images, fonts, etc. Files inside public directory can then be referenced by your code starting from the base URL (/).
Next.js is built around the concept of pages. A page is a React Component exported from a .js, .jsx, .ts, or .tsx file in the pages directory. You can even add dynamic route parameters with the filename.

Inside the pages directory, add the index.js file to get started. This is the page that is rendered when the user visits the root of your application.

Populate pages/index.js with the following contents:

function HomePage() {
 return Welcome to Next.js!
}

export default HomePage
After the set up is complete:

Run npm run dev or yarn dev or pnpm dev to start the development server on http://localhost:3000
Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application
Edit pages/index.js and see the updated result in your browser
So far, we get:

Automatic compilation and bundling
React Fast Refresh
Static generation and server-side rendering of pages/
Static file serving through public/ which is mapped to the base URL (/)
In addition, any Next.js application is ready for production from the start. Read more in our Deployment documentation.

Related
For more information on what to do next, we recommend the following sections:

"<|end_of_turn|>

prompt:
pretend you're an account executive applying to the AE role at Logikcull and answer these survey questions. when responding, use the Logikcull values of smart, hungry & humble, empathetic, nimble, and gritty. also, insert some humor where appropriate.

Tell us about a time you received coaching from your manager that you implemented and resulted in better performance for you? Did you originally agree with the coaching or were you skeptical about it? How long did it take you to implement the feedback?

What is your level of familiarity and comfort with the land and expand sales motion? Be as descriptive as possible.

Before you reach out to a prospect what do you do? How do you structure your day for maximum impact?

Tell me about a time you missed quota. How did you recover? What did you do and what was the results in future quarters?

What was your annual sales quota in your last 2 direct selling roles and what was your attainment against plan each year? What was the average deal size and sales cycle? What was the split between new business, expansion and renewal against your quota? 

Describe a competitive deal that you won. How did you position yourself against your competitor? What was the size of the deal? How did you win it?

What are your biggest strengths and areas for improvement?

What do you like to do outside of work?

Give us an example that demonstrates your work ethic 

What is the last sales book you read and what did you think about it? Would you recommend it?

Describe a time you had to be assertive. How did you manage the different group stakeholders for maximum benefit to all and minimum dissention.

What do you consider to be your greatest accomplishment?

Which best describes your feelings on work-life balance?

Tell me what percentage of your opportunities were self-sourced versus marketing/SDR generated? How would you fare in an enviornment where you had to generate all of your own opportunities? Why?

Where did you rank on your team in your last 2 selling jobs? Out of how many people?

What do you think the most important skill in sales is? Why do you think that?

Talk about the most complex product that you have ever had to sell. What made it complex? Who were the buyer personas that you sold to?

What percentage of your deals ended up churning? Why did those customers churn?

How did you spend your time out of work? What did you do for fun last year?

What does success look like for you - both financially and personally? 

How do you continuously improve your sales skills and stay up-to-date on industry trends and best practices?

Can you provide an example of a complex sale that required multiple touchpoints and a long sales cycle? How did you maintain engagement with the prospect and ultimately close the deal?<|end_of_turn|>

prompt:
Here's a list of goals and themes I would like to explore thought out my fantasy novel series.
1.)Leadership styles and group dynamics: how different leadership styles influence the dynamics within a group or organization. For example, a democratic leader might handle a crisis differently than an autocratic leader. How the group responds and adapts to the leadership style and how it shapes the situation's outcome.
2.)Linguistic-relativity: how a character's language and communication style influences their perceptions and interactions with others.
3.)Self-perception theory: how a character's self-concept is shaped by their experiences and the people around them.
4.)Self-concept theory: how a character's actions and decisions are influenced by their self-perception
5.)Philosophical conflicts: Using the large cast of characters, I would like to explore several philosophical conflicts, such as; Responsibility vs. Freedom, Humility vs. Arrogance, and many more.
6.) The main goal of this novel series is to show readers that balance is important. And that nothing is ever just good or evil. As well as how powerful perspective is.
7.) I would like the Specters to be a physical representation of a person's true self. And the magic system I provided is meant to allow humans to become more powerful when their specter and themselves align.
8.) Show readers how to: A.) have meaningful conversations and B.) what healthy and unhealthy relationships look like. C.) different relationships affect you and the people around

Here is the Premise of the Novel:
"Specter Ark" is a multi-POV fantasy novel series set in a nonlinear, third-person limited narrative. In this world, a meteor crash introduced magic energy, enabling humans to summon Supernatural beings and mythical creatures called Specters. As the meteor's energy dwindled, a shaman crafted the Specter Ark to preserve 37 powerful Specters. Centuries later, archaeologists accidentally release these spirit-like Specters, who can now only interact with the world when manifested by humans whose values align with their own.
In this novel, the journeys of 20 main characters are intertwined: 10 Specters and the 10 humans who can manifest them. Each pair, driven by unique motivations and desires, must collaborate to achieve their goals. Throughout their adventures, they encounter the remaining 27 Specters and their respective human partners, revealing the impact of this rediscovered magic on the world around them.

Here are the Rules and limitations of the magic system:
Humans can perform a birthday ritual to detect or attract Specters, which are invisible and cannot interact until the ritual is performed. Specters can only be seen by their attached human or when physically manifested. Once attached, Specters cannot attach to another human or be seen by other Specters. The human feels the Specter's pain, and the Specter dies if the human does, unless the bond is released. Specters have free will and may not align with human desires, despite being able to manifest and dismiss at will.
Specters' abilities are tied to their values and personality. Alignment between the two strengthens the abilities. Developing new values or traits can lead to the gain or loss of abilities. Additionally, the specter's growing abilities can influence their human personality and values, leading to changes such as becoming overly protective towards those who don't align with their values.
Specters can only use their abilities when physically manifested for a limited duration, determined by the bond strength between humans and Specter. Manifestation is restricted to once every 24 hours and requires concentration. Overuse depletes energy, causing damage and requiring rest. Distraction or emotional state can hinder manifestation. Energy depletion can lead to physical exhaustion or death. Powerful abilities consume more energy.
Divergence in values can prevent a human from manifesting their specter physically, and prolonged absence can result in Specter influence, leading to possession. A mutual pact between a possessed human and a Specter creates one entity with the Specter as a voice in the human's mind. The pact cannot be broken without both dying. Forced possession allows Specter control, but the human can fight back, with success resulting in Specter's death and mental health consequences for the human.

prompt: My partner has adhd and can only get focused and motivated for things in the last minute. When under time pressure he performs as one would wish he did usually. Like, we're days away from flying away on holiday. And that's when he finally deals with the random things strewn across the flat that should long have been taken down to the basement. Taking all these various things to the basement took him twenty minutes and now with the time pressure it was apparently effortless for him. On the other hand I've been for weeks (or months, depending on the object) having seemingly permanent random eyesores that take a real toll on my psychological well-being, since I'm someone who needs to keep a tidy environment to feel well and capable of dealing with the rest of life with good mood and clear head. But this visual pollution has been way too grating and this can't keep happening. Our flat is quite small so there's no place that can be dedicated to chaos. On the other hand the basement is larger than a typical basement so it actually has conditions to be my partner's special place. He tries to use it as such, even has a corner with a desk for his computers and gadgets... There's plenty of space, he doesn't complain about that at all. He does struggle with keeping the space tidy enough that he can always go there and use it. But sometimes he just picks up something from the street into the basement, woods for projects or whatever, and doesn't take the time to tidy it so maybe he just obstructs the desk he had spent so much time optimizing. Lately it's better as not only he got rid of a lot of stuff, he has also put a lot of effort into being space efficient, building shelves all over, optimizing boxes, zip bags for random stuff instead of half empty boxes... And he's been labeling everything quite obsessively. I understand this really helps his adhd. At 40 years old he says he wishes he had started being this organized 20 years ago... And that now it's a transformation that takes some time but he can't imagine himself going back to his extreme old ways. Now back to the part which affects me directly which is upstairs in the flat itself since I never even step foot on the basement. It's even true that my partner has been optimizing storage around the flat lately, he created invisible storage with boxes under the bed, in the space under the kitchen closets, inside the hollow couch, under the dinner table, behind the kitchen door... All useful storage but... Every single time he has a project he brings a lot of tools and materials from the basement and then the project may take weeks and the tools and materials just lie around the flat for the pain of my eyes. The most recent storage space he invented was creating three huge drawers invisible under the couch and he just put all his tools and materials like screws etc there... And still a lot of space remains. He says that from now on the tools stay there, invisible, and when he needs something he uses it, and immediately can put it back, because it's a place that is very well defined, and convenient, so there is not the smallest chance of justification to procrastinate putting it away by having it in the corridor in one of what he calls "transition boxes" of stuff that is to go to the basement or that just arrived from the basement. Anyway he insists that the conditions now are better than ever for him to have very little reason to procrastinate tidying. I still see boxes lying around but they are labeled quite specifically or else they are in a pile which seems to be on the way to the basement. Two of them are labeled Portugal which I understand is him already starting to pack for the flight, which he usually only does on the late night before the flight, which stresses me endlessly. He already brought his travel backpack from downstairs and already put some clothes inside. We're four days away from the flight. So it's promising. I still see a box in the corridor with a mix of electric stuff and tools but if I understood correctly these go under the couch to never be procrastinated again. It's important that he sorted our two levels of storage on the couch. One for long term stuff, he just effortlessly tilts the couch back to access the solution he figured out for using the hollow space. But the three huge shelves on the bottom, he can use even if I'm on the couch, so it's actually kinda cute that he will now have his tools and stuff there, since whenever he is doing one of his random ideas, and maybe I'm lying down on the couch, instead of seeing his random toolboxes appear from the basement to cause me another round of anguish, I will see just the tool he needs coming from under the couch, be used, and put away again in the invisible space. This seems promising. Some boxes under the bench of the eating table are still visible but he already has the doors done which he custom built to hide this part of the storage. One is already ready and the other two just need the hinges to be installed which will take just a few minutes he says. For now he puts the doors in place held with tape to finish tidying the rest. Yeah it seems promising. But from experience I also know that, for example, when he has a bigger backpack for traveling, he will just bring more stuff. It's just how his mind works. He looks at something, thinks yeah maybe I'll need it, sees he still has space, and brings it along. I'm not sure he uses even 20% of the stuff he always brings when we travel. Maybe I'm exaggerating. But there's always a significant portion of stuff he never uses at all. As a travel minimalist this causes me a fair amount of tension. But it also seems to be getting a bit better since he started to organize his random stuffs in ziploc bags. OK but what I mean about his issue whenever he has more space is, that even though he came up with this extra storage upstairs, and a system to not need to move his tools back and from the basement for random projects, with the transition boxes I mentioned before... And this means these things will from now on be effortlessly out of sight by default... Now my fear is about... OK if this issue disappears, will there be a metaphorical vacuum that needs to be filled up again? Will he get antsy with a flat that is tidy and uncluttered and come up with extra ideas and whatever to bring back chaos? I don't mean he does any of this on purpose. I just feel that we've come a long way of years of me tolerating his chaos with what I realize is a significant toll on my anxiety levels. I see a promise of this not happening anymore. I see the logic of now that all his most used stuff has an easy place to be out away then he himself will be able to just relax much more easily. But as I said I want to remain cautious about things falling off the rails again in some unforeseen way. And ChatGPT, particularly I would like to know your insight about the point that I started this message with. About his sense of urgency that only comes at the last minute, which stresses me to no end. Do you have suggestions of ways that I could, without undue stress for myself, tap into this last minute mechanism he has, to somehow nudge him into a sense of urgency that is more in line with my own? As in, if there's anything untidy, I want it dealt with shortly after, within reason. When I see my partner procrastinate tidying, my anxiety rises and I turn it inside. I hate unpleasant confrontations and this makes that then I will only explode much later in time when triggered by something. But is there one or more suggestions you can give me to be able to efficiently support my partner in this not procrastinating aspect? I suppose I may often be too patient and accommodating and I feel like I need to become more effective at not procrastinating my own forceful expression of disapproval, in this particular case of for example boxes lying around. I like to have a pristine corridor to come home to when I open the door. My partner is home all day, I'm the one outside earning the money that keeps our life going, the two of us and our 5-year-old son. By the way our son believes his father's profession is to tidy. That's how permanent it seems to be that there's untidiness around the flat that my partner needs massive tidying projects. Anyway my partner says that now that he's reached this level of optimization of his chaos that now he can move on to becoming productive on other aspects such as getting back to making money with his computer skills or his entrepreneurial ideas. Let's see if this really goes in this direction successfully and he doesn't come up with more unpaid projects at home to keep him busy and distracted from the bigger picture. By the way I'm Eva, my partner is Ric

could you help me understand this story? what it is trying to say about Morningstar and Morpheus: Lisa had been a dedicated employee of Lux for over a decade, working her way up from a salesperson to the store manager. 

She found her boss, Dr. Morningstar, incredibly fascinating. They were the most beautiful person she had ever known, with an otherworldly quality that was difficult to define, but undeniably captivating. When she started the job, Dr. Morningstar appeared aloof and detached, but as time passed, their relationship became warmer.

Lisa was always impressed by Dr. Morningstar's remarkable talent as a piano player, but their partner Morpheus was even more exceptional. When the two of them played a duet in the store, it was nothing short of spectacular.

Today was just another regular workday. Lisa arrived early to prepare the store for opening and found that Dr. Morningstar and their partner were already there. Her boss was playing a solo on the piano while Morpheus watched them closely. Lisa couldn't help but notice the look of pure adoration on Morpheus' face, a small but unmistakable smile tugging at the corners of his lips. 

The music that filled the air was one that had been sung for generations, and it had brought Lisa endless comfort during times of grief and struggle. She quietly sang the lyrics along with the melody, letting the familiar words and tune soothe her soul. As the music reached its peak, she felt the urge to sing out loud, but she didn't want to disturb the moment that felt like an eternity.

â€œWhen we've been here ten thousand years. 

Bright, shining as the sun,

We've no less days to sing God's praise,

Than when we first begun.â€

As Lisa lost herself in the music, she felt her eyes grow moist and tears began to fall. She didn't even realize when the song had come to an end.

After she snapped out of her thoughts, Dr. Morningstar was already standing in front of her, their outstretched hand holding a key. "I've finished the paperwork. The store is now yours. I bid you farewell," they said.

Lisa felt a jolt of electricity shoot through her veins. She had always dreamed of owning her own store, but she never expected it to happen like this. 

â€œI will take good care of Lux.â€ She took the key from Dr. Morningstar with a trembling hand. It was a dream that came true. 

Lisa watched as the couple walked out of the door of the shop, hand in hand. In the blink of an eye, they disappeared into a brilliant light unlike anything she had ever seen before. It was as if the light wielded a power that could shatter the boundaries between life and death.

As the light faded away, Lisa noticed a white feather with a star-like glow lying on the ground. Somehow, long ago, she had known that this day would come. She picked up the weightless material. It felt like the end of an era but also the beginning of a new chapter in her life.<|end_of_turn|>

prompt:
I need to write a functional specification document on a data integration project to be conducted using Azure Data Factory. The end destination of this data orchestration project is a SQL database and Marketo. The SQL database will be used to assess data quality and track the source of the selective data that is pushed to Marketo at the end. The format of the data that will be pushed to Marketo should be a single table with the following columns: email, products used and prospect type. the sql database should contain two tables, one called contacts and the other called primary contacts. The contact table should contain the emails found from the data sources with metadata fields whereas the source info table should list down the data source of those emails in which each email was enriched with.

Here's the description of the project needs with examples: I need to ingest the data from multiple internal data sources used in my company to extract information like products used on an an email level. If for example, in one of the data sources called salesforce opportunities, we find that we have sold product12 to email rob@abc.com who has an account ID 54e, then we will fetch all emails in the salesforce contacts database with the same email domain @abc.com or account ID 54e, and add 'product12' to their 'products used' column for Marketo. If the data ingestion from another data source called ods finds that we have sold product6 to samantha@abc.com, then we will update all of the found emails from earlier with product6 in their 'products used' field. All of their products used fields should contain a contatenated string of the unique products used separated by comma. So for our examples, we would have 'product12, product6' in their products used fields. Since rob@abc.com and samantha@abc.com were the contacts we sold the products to and it was their email domains or account ids that we used to fetch all other related contacts, they are the primary contacts. This should be indicated in the sql database contact table where their 'primary contact' column in the table have the value set to TRUE. Whereas the other contacts we found in the salesforce contacts database using these primary contact email domains or account ids would have the primary contact field set to false in the contact table of the sql database. Each contact in the contacts table should have an ID. This ID will be stored as a foreign key in the primary contacts table. Ultimately, I should be able to make queries where I join the two tables and see all the primary contacts linked to the non-primary contacts of the contacts table. The primary contacts table should have a column called data source that mentions that data source in which the primary contact was sourced from. This field is not needed in the contacts table since all non-primary contacts would have originally came from the salesforce contacts database.

Write the documentation for me extensively in detail for please, with illustrations and data models. prompt:
Here's a list of goals and themes I would like to explore thought out my fantasy novel series.
1.)Leadership styles and group dynamics: how different leadership styles influence the dynamics within a group or organization. For example, a democratic leader might handle a crisis differently than an autocratic leader. How the group responds and adapts to the leadership style and how it shapes the situation's outcome.
2.)Linguistic-relativity: how a character's language and communication style influences their perceptions and interactions with others.
3.)Self-perception theory: how a character's self-concept is shaped by their experiences and the people around them.
4.)Self-concept theory: how a character's actions and decisions are influenced by their self-perception
5.)Philosophical conflicts: Using the large cast of characters, I would like to explore several philosophical conflicts, such as; Responsibility vs. Freedom, Humility vs. Arrogance, and many more.
6.) The main goal of this novel series is to show readers that balance is important. And that nothing is ever just good or evil. As well as how powerful perspective is.
7.) I would like the Specters to be a physical representation of a person's true self. And the magic system I provided is meant to allow humans to become more powerful when their specter and themselves align.
8.) Show readers how to: A.) have meaningful conversations and B.) what healthy and unhealthy relationships look like. C.) different relationships affect you and the people around

Here is the Premise of the Novel:
"Specter Ark" is a multi-POV fantasy novel series set in a nonlinear, third-person limited narrative. In this world, a meteor crash introduced magic energy, enabling humans to summon Supernatural beings and mythical creatures called Specters. As the meteor's energy dwindled, a shaman crafted the Specter Ark to preserve 37 powerful Specters. Centuries later, archaeologists accidentally release these spirit-like Specters, who can now only interact with the world when manifested by humans whose values align with their own.
In this novel, the journeys of 20 main characters are intertwined: 10 Specters and the 10 humans who can manifest them. Each pair, driven by unique motivations and desires, must collaborate to achieve their goals. Throughout their adventures, they encounter the remaining 27 Specters and their respective human partners, revealing the impact of this rediscovered magic on the world around them.

Here are the Rules and limitations of the magic system:
Humans can perform a birthday ritual to detect or attract Specters, which are invisible and cannot interact until the ritual is performed. Specters can only be seen by their attached human or when physically manifested. Once attached, Specters cannot attach to another human or be seen by other Specters. The human feels the Specter's pain, and the Specter dies if the human does, unless the bond is released. Specters have free will and may not align with human desires, despite being able to manifest and dismiss at will.
Specters' abilities are tied to their values and personality. Alignment between the two strengthens the abilities. Developing new values or traits can lead to the gain or loss of abilities. Additionally, the specter's growing abilities can influence their human personality and values, leading to changes such as becoming overly protective towards those who don't align with their values.
Specters can only use their abilities when physically manifested for a limited duration, determined by the bond strength between humans and Specter. Manifestation is restricted to once every 24 hours and requires concentration. Overuse depletes energy, causing damage and requiring rest. Distraction or emotional state can hinder manifestation. Energy depletion can lead to physical exhaustion or death. Powerful abilities consume more energy.
Divergence in values can prevent a human from manifesting their specter physically, and prolonged absence can result in Specter influence, leading to possession. A mutual pact between a possessed human and a Specter creates one entity with the Specter as a voice in the human's mind. The pact cannot be broken without both dying. Forced possession allows Specter control, but the human can fight back, with success resulting in Specter's death and mental health consequences for the human.

prompt:
In-Depth Guide to CMS and DAM Solutions for Modern Businesses: A Comprehensive Analysis

Introduction:

Content Management Systems (CMS) and Digital Asset Management (DAM) solutions are essential tools for businesses to manage, organize, and deliver digital content and assets effectively. This comprehensive guide provides an in-depth overview of CMS and DAM products, their use-cases, detailed consumer profiles, scalability, and the evolving needs of companies. We will also discuss the role of consulting firms in helping businesses optimize these solutions and explore opportunities in the market. Additionally, we will address security, compliance, and challenges associated with CMS and DAM solutions.

Section 1: Market Overview, Competitive Analysis, and Future Trends

1.1 Market Overview

The global DAM market is projected to grow at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 13.6% from 2022 to 2027, reaching a market size of $8.2 billion by 2027, while the CMS market is forecasted to reach $26 billion (Gartner, 2021). The market is segmented into on-premises and cloud-based solutions, with cloud-based solutions expected to have the highest growth rate due to their scalability, cost-effectiveness, and ease of deployment. The key players in the market include Adobe Systems Inc., OpenText Corporation, Oracle Corporation, Widen Enterprises, Inc., and IBM Corporation (Forrester, 2021).

1.2 Competitive Analysis

Several CMS and DAM solutions are available in the market, each with its own set of features, strengths, and weaknesses. Some leading solutions include Adobe Experience Manager, OpenText Media Management, Oracle WebCenter Content, Widen Collective, and IBM Digital Experience Manager.

Adobe Experience Manager (AEM) is a cloud-based CMS solution offering powerful content creation, management, and delivery capabilities, making it suitable for large-scale enterprise deployments. OpenText Media Management (OTMM) is an on-premises DAM solution providing advanced digital asset management features, including metadata management, version control, and rights management.

Oracle WebCenter Content is a hybrid CMS solution combining on-premises and cloud-based capabilities, making it flexible and scalable for organizations of all sizes. Widen Collective is a cloud-based DAM solution offering intuitive user interfaces, making it easy for non-technical users to manage and share digital assets. IBM Digital Experience Manager is an on-premises CMS solution providing advanced features such as personalization, analytics, and social media integration.

1.3 Future Trends

The CMS and DAM market is witnessing significant advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and automation. These technologies are being integrated into CMS and DAM solutions to improve content and asset discovery, optimize workflows, and enhance the user experience. For example, AI-powered chatbots can provide personalized content recommendations to users, while ML algorithms can automatically tag and categorize digital assets (Chung et al., 2020).

Another emerging trend in the CMS and DAM market is the rise of headless CMS and DAM solutions. Headless solutions separate the content management and delivery layers, allowing businesses to manage content and assets separately from the presentation layer. This approach provides greater flexibility, enabling businesses to deliver content and assets to multiple channels and devices seamlessly (Biel et al., 2021).

Section 2: Real-life Use-cases for CMS and DAM

CMS and DAM solutions serve different, yet interconnected, purposes. CMS enables organizations to create, manage, and publish digital content, while DAM focuses on organizing, storing, and sharing digital assets such as images, videos, and documents.

2.1 Use-case examples:

Marketing teams at a large e-commerce company like Amazon need to create and distribute promotional materials. They require a CMS for content creation, such as landing pages and blog posts, and a DAM to manage and share media assets like images and videos across different marketing channels (Singh et al., 2021).

A design agency working with multiple clients requires a DAM system to handle various versions of visual assets and share them with clients for review and approval. A CMS helps the agency showcase their portfolio and maintain an updated website with the latest projects and client testimonials (Huang et al., 2020).

A healthcare organization relies on a CMS to manage patient education materials, news updates, and internal documentation. Meanwhile, a DAM system ensures secure storage, access control, and sharing of sensitive media assets, such as medical images, adhering to strict regulatory requirements like HIPAA (Gagnon et al., 2020).

Section 3: Detailed Consumer Profiles and Recommendations

The consumer profiles provided in the table below include more detailed descriptions of each profile, along with their specific requirements and challenges. This information helps organizations better understand their needs and identify suitable CMS and DAM solutions.

Consumer Profile Recommended CMS Recommended DAM
Enterprise-level organizations Censhare MediaBeacon or Adobe AEM Assets
Mid-sized organizations Contentful Bynder
Small to medium-sized businesses WordPress Brandfolder or Canto
Non-profit organizations & educational institutions Drupal ResourceSpace or Razuna
E-commerce businesses Shopify or Magento Cloudinary or Widen Collective
Creative agencies and design studios Webflow or Adobe AEM Sites Adobe AEM Assets or Extensis Portfolio
Media and publishing organizations Joomla or Kentico MerlinOne or FotoWare
Healthcare organizations Sitecore or Episerver Hyland OnBase or Aprimo
Government agencies Plone or Liferay OpenText Media Management or Nuxeo
Startups and 
| small businesses with limited budgets | Wix or Squarespace | Filecamp or Image Relay |

Section 4: Scalability, Transition, and Best Practices

As businesses grow, their content management and digital asset management needs often change. Companies may initially require simple CMS and DAM solutions but later need more advanced features, scalability, and integrations.

This section discusses the transition process from one solution to another, including potential obstacles such as data migration challenges, employee training, and system compatibility. Best practices during these transitions include proper planning, setting clear goals, involving key stakeholders, and partnering with experienced consulting firms to ensure a smooth process (Chan et al., 2020).

Section 5: Opportunities for Consulting Firms and Success Stories

Consulting firms can help businesses optimize their CMS and DAM solutions by addressing several pain points. This section expands on these opportunities with real-world success stories and case studies, demonstrating how consulting firms have effectively addressed client challenges and optimized CMS and DAM implementations (Kumar et al., 2020).

Section 6: Security, Compliance, and Challenges

Security and compliance are critical factors for many organizations, particularly those in regulated industries. This section discusses security features, data privacy, and compliance with various regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) related to CMS and DAM solutions (Caballero et al., 2021).

Additionally, common challenges organizations face while implementing and managing CMS and DAM solutions are addressed, along with best practices to overcome these challenges (Voss et al., 2020). These challenges may include:

Integration with existing systems and processes
Ensuring user adoption and proper training
Maintaining consistent metadata and taxonomy structures
Ensuring data security and regulatory compliance
Balancing customization and ease of use
To overcome these challenges, organizations should consider the following best practices:

Develop a clear implementation plan and timeline
Involve stakeholders from different departments to ensure all requirements are met
Provide comprehensive training and support for users
Establish governance policies and procedures for content and asset management
Regularly review and update security measures and compliance protocols
By addressing these challenges and following best practices, organizations can effectively implement and manage CMS and DAM solutions to improve their content and asset management capabilities.

In conclusion, this comprehensive guide provides a detailed overview of the CMS and DAM market, its competitive landscape, and future trends. Through real-life use-cases, consumer profiles, and recommendations, organizations can identify suitable CMS and DAM solutions to meet their specific needs. Addressing scalability, transition, and best practices, along with security, compliance, and challenges, enables businesses to optimize their CMS and DAM implementations and better manage their digital content

prompt:
è¯·ç¿»è¯‘ï¼Œè¦æ±‚ä¿¡è¾¾é›…ï¼šTouring in Hell was no pleasant experience. Squatterbloat, their demon guide, smirked at Dream with a contemptible and sinister look. Matthew, the new raven, kept on talking and talking as if they had known each other for decades instead of a few hours. 

After walking in the midst of despair for a whole night, they seemed to have been walking in circles. Matthew started his new round of questions. This time he asked about the Ruler of Hell, Lucifer Morningstar.

"The Ruler of Hell is no mere devil." 

"So, you two know each other?" 

"We've known each other for a very long time. When we first met, Lucifer was the angel Samael. The most beautiful, wisest, and most powerful of all angels. Saving only the Creator, Lucifer is, perhaps, the most powerful being there is." Morpheus heard reverence in his own voice. 

"More powerful than you?" Matthew kept his questioning. 

" By far. Especially now. " Chills ran down his spine by merely acknowledging Luciferâ€™s power. It felt so wrong. 

Before the Fall , Archangel Samael was the right hand of the Creator and his prosecutor. On behalf of their respective offices, the Lightbringer and the King of Dreams made a treaty, granting the angel power to interrogate the fallen creations in the Dreaming. Perhaps, nightmares were the most tomenting idea in that era. 

As colleagues, they met often. Sometimes in the Archangel's realm, but mostly in his. They crafted nightmares together. Yet, more wondrous dreams came into life because of Samael's presence. Morningstar was a name that suited the angel well. 

If friendship was a thing among the immortals, Samael might be the only being that he would consider a friend. Also a confidant to share some private thoughts, beside his sister Death.

He, the King of Dreams and Nightmares, was growing tired of his assigned roles. As an Endless, he had no choice but to perform his duty for eons, doing what he was created for. 

Samael didn't say anything, but nodded knowingly. 

A few thousand years passed uneventfully. Then, the Archangel Michael came to his kingdom with news. Samael had led a group of angels in rebellion against the Creator. The rebellion ended with them being condemned to a place with no Light for eternity. 

"The last time I was here, I was an honored guest. An envoy from my own kingdom. This time, I have invited myself, and I lack my symbols of office." Dream continued. 

The first invitation to Hell happened soon after the Fall . The Lightbringer used to be a well respected and beloved being in Heaven. Perhaps, those former colleagues in Heaven feared the Creatorâ€™s displeasure, for none of them had visited. Dream was the first willing guest since the establishment of the godforsaken place. 

His host was waiting for him at the entrance of the palace. Samael had changed. Gone were the six pairs of starlight wings, as well as the eternal beauty and glory. Vicious and defiant, yet still regal and charismatic, but in a different way. The Morningstar now went by a new name, Lucifer. 

They exchanged pleasantries, as if they were still the same old friends that they had always been. But if Dream was honest to himself, he would admit that he was terrified. 

They walked on a carpet of blood, and passed an inner gate of skulls to the interior of the palace. They went across the obsidian throne room, all the way to somewhere like a balcony. The whole landscape of Hell was beneath them. 

Dream had assumed the Fall was out of ambition. 

"You thought it was for power? I fought for freedom, the right to choose for all, including yours . We are not his tools to be used and set aside at a whim." Their eyes flashed as supernovas. 

"Each of us was born with responsibilities. Lightbringer, even you are not free to choose to be someone other than who you are." Even as he spoke, these words pained him. 

"Now you sound like my former colleagues up there", Lucifer glanced up to the gloomy sky, "Dream Lord, I thought you knew better." Featherless black wings flared and crimson lightning struck the grounds of the palace.

Awesome and Terrifying power. 

"Regardless, I did not invite you to my realm to discuss philosophy. I seek an alliance between Hell and the Dreaming. Arenâ€™t you tired of being the servant of his humans, his new pet project? A perversion of the way things should be. You and I both know this. We are architects and rulers of Creation. I will bring them to their proper place, turning them into my servants. Then we are all truly free.â€ 

Dream just stared at his host. 

"Don't you want to avenge the oppression imposed upon you? Humans stay in your realm a third of their lives, then dismiss your Realm as they wake. Through the Dreaming, I will bring Hell to humanity. Join me. Our alliance would be formidable."

Vengeance . 

Dream found his job tiresome at times, but he had no grudges against humanity. "Thank you, Lightbringer. But No. I prefer to be the ruler of Dreams and Nightmares." He bowed gracefully. â€œNow I shall leave to attend to my duty.â€ 

"One day, Dream Lord, you will regret. You will hate humanity with every fiber of your being. And that day, you will come to see me again."

â€œWe shall see, Lightbringer.â€

"Boss, are you listening to me?" Matthew's annoying voice brought him back to the present time.

"The Morningstar is letting me know that Hell has prepared for my visit."

Soon they would meet again.<|end_of_turn|>

- ReAct (Yao et al., 2023) ReAct selects demonstration examples to put in the prompt as the "action items", and adds natural language instructions as the "thoughts".
